comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: On the 11th of February, 1941 there was just one naval display in Sydney. The officers and crew of HMAS Sydney (II) marched through the city on their way to Town Hall for a presentation. They were honoured for their action sinking the Italian warship Bartolomeo Colleoni. I give some of the details of the event on my blog here: lifeasdaddy.typepad.com/lifeasdaddy/2009/07/powerhouse-mu... The white uniformed officer standing in front of this group is very likely Captain John A. Collins. With an enlargement I could identify him. Bebarfalds Furniture was located opposite the Sydney Town Hall, so this photograph was taken at the conclusion of the march through the city. Here are some details about the building: www.hht.net.au/discover/highlights/online_exhibitions/syd... ADDED: The event was reported on page 11 of the Sydney Morning Herald the next day: news.google.com/newspapers?id=SEwRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BZUDA... collins&pg=7213,4672158 " Captain Collins, proud and obviously greatly moved by the warmth of the demonstration, drew his men up in ranks outside the Town Hall ... " And here on page 14 of the Sydney Morning Herald is a photograph of the same scene taken from a higher viewpoint: news.google.com/newspapers?id=SEwRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BZUDA... collins&pg=7510,4690557

comment._content: Is this the building that there is talk (in 2009) of pulling down?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: frontdrive34 - I think this building currently houses Woolworths at ground level, but I don't know if there is talk of pulling it down.

comment.author: 27818381@N04
comment._content: love all the people sitting on the window ledges! :)

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Yes there was talk of pulling it down, to make an open public space opposite town hall. I don't know what the current situation with it is though!

comment.author: 44919466@N02
comment._content: Each Christmas during the 1950s my sister and I were taken to the Bebarfald's Building to have our photos taken with Santa Claus.  We love the photos and the memories they bring of Sydney at that time.  All the big stores had beautiful window displays.  Grace Brothers at Broadway had an amazing walk-through Christmas Wonderland!

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The City of Sydney owns the building and it is leased to Woolworths. City of Sydney owns some of the adjacent properties aswell, acquired some time ago to create a civic square opposite the Sydney Town Hall. Obviously the City has to justify significant loss of income, asset value write down plus capital outlay for the square, so it is not an easy call. RailCorp might bite the bullet and attack the abomination known as Town Hall Railway Station and that might trigger something.
